p: One of the first sign of intraplantar injection of CAR, was the increase in paw volume in a time-dependent way ( Figure 1A) measured at 8 different set point from 0 (time when the experiment started) to 6 h (time when experiment ended). The increase in paw volume leads to pain that was assessed by the development of thermal hyperalgesia ( Figure 1B) and mechanical allodynia ( Figure 1C). In our study, we found that oral treatment with Cashew nuts at the dose of 100 mg/kg given 30 min before CAR, showed a reduction of the volume of rat paw significantly at 6 h post-CAR as well as a decrease in pain showing an inflammatory activity and algesic response.
